sp.processors

Class CollectionWrapperProcessor

  • java.lang.Object
    • sp.processors.PtAnnotationProcessor
      • sp.processors.CollectionWrapperProcessor

  • public class CollectionWrapperProcessor
extends PtAnnotationProcessor
    This annotation processor processes the Future annotations that appear at the declaration of a collection (i.e., List, Set, Map, Collection for other types), in order to obtain collection wrappers that can contain both variables and future variables.
    For example: myList is a List that calls on ParaTask for a collection wrapper. The object can either add future variables, or make direct calls on only one method (e.g., myList.add(foo(a)). That method MUST be annotated with the Task annotation. If 'myList' invokes a method (e.g., add), for which the argument is a statement and not an invocation expression (e.g., myList.add(foo(2) + foo(3))), the operation is performed sequentially iff the methods are not annotated with Task. However, if a method is annotated with Task it is executed asynchronously, but the invocation blocks until the result from that asynchronous task is back. That is, the corresponding future variable will not be added to the container, rather the container waits until the result from the asynchronous task is back.
    Since:
    2016
    Author:
    Mostafa Mehrabi
